docs.lead_paragraph: In the condominiums and on the palm-shaded beaches here, where Medicare is a frequent topic of conversation, few people expect to get much help from the new drug benefit just approved by Congress. They express disappointment but little surprise because, they say, they never had high hopes. They say they feel they were sold out, by Republicans and AARP, which endorsed a Medicare bill drafted mainly by Republicans. But the Democrats, they say, did not fight hard enough for a better drug benefit.

headline.main: Florida Elderly Feel Let Down By Medicare Drug Benefit

docs.abstract: Elderly Florida residents express disappointment but little surprise that they will not get much help from Medicare drug benefit newly approved by Congress, interviews, Hollywood, Fla; complain of being sold out by Republicans and AARP, which endorsed bill; say Democrats did not fight hard enough for better drug benefit; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In the condominiums and on the palm-shaded beaches here, where Medicare is a frequent topic of conversation, few people expect to get much help from the new drug benefit just approved by Congress.    They express disappointment but little surprise...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Medicare bill passed by Congress last week includes sizable increases in payments to hospitals, but under formulas intended mostly to help small-town hospitals, little of that money will go to the New York metropolitan area. The bill, which President Bush has said he will sign, does not have the wide range of reductions in Medicare payments to hospitals that were included in earlier versions, cuts that would have hit New York hardest. Rather than cutting payments to hospitals, the final version provides a $13.5 billion increase over 10 years to hospitals nationwide under Medicare, the federal health plan for the elderly and for disabled people.

headline.main: City Hospitals Gain Little in Medicare Bill

docs.abstract: New Medicare bill passed by Congress, which President Bush says he will sign, will only increase funding to New York City, Long Island, and Westchester and Rockland County (NY) hospitals by $60 million over 10 years, while increasing payments to hospitals nationwide by $13.5 billion over 10 years; map (M)
docs.snippet: The Medicare bill passed by Congress last week includes sizable increases in payments to hospitals, but under formulas intended mostly to help small-town hospitals, little of that money will go to the New York metropolitan area.    The bill, which...

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a recent Monday afternoon, men gathered like crows around a black Lamborghini parked outside the Pierre Hotel. Tucked into their dark suits, they all had the conspicuous sheen that comes from a lifetime of elliptical training, beef cheeks and Château Margaux. The car was up for auction at a black-tie event for 500 people inside the hotel. The men will remain unidentified because this is the Pierre, a province of the old world, where the rich worked hard to stay out of newspapers rather than get in them.

headline.main: Those Who Serve, Those Who Are Served

docs.abstract: Article on discreet luxury of Hotel Pierre in Manhattan, which has been owned by co-op since 1959; 30 of 76 co-op owners live at Pierre permanently, their apartments scattered among 201 guest rooms; duties of several staff members, including bartender Joe Dacchille and elevator operator Khady Gueyesall, described; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR small businesses, hiring employees and administering benefits can be big headaches. Gevity HR and Administaff are companies that take on these burdens for other businesses. Shares of each company have soared this year, and some investors contend that they will continue to rise as the economy expands.

headline.main: Investing; For Benefits Managers, a Very Good Year

docs.abstract: Strong stock performance of Gevity HR and Administaff, two companies that handle payroll and benefits for small businesses, discussed; stock price graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NELLIE MENDEZ, 26, of Hempstead sat patiently in the emergency room of Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, waiting for a doctor to examine her 9-month-old son, Jeffrey. ''He was crying a lot last night and couldn't breathe,'' she said in Spanish. ''He's better now, but I feel he's still having some trouble, so I want him checked out.''

headline.main: Med Center: Vital Signs Are Slipping

docs.abstract: Article on deficits and staff layoffs that are adversely impacting services at Nassau University Medical Center; hospital, busiest on Long Island, sees 420,000 patients each year; eight percent of inpatients and 26 percent of outpatients are uninsured; Nassau County and other governments subsidize about $50 million out of $70 million worth of uninsured services; Nassau Health Care Corp is awash in red ink; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a perfectly equitable world, would the government have passed legislation that would give older Americans a prescription drug care plan that will cost $400 billion over 10 years? To some economists, the prescription-drug benefit approved by Congress last Tuesday looks like Robin Hood in reverse. After all, there are millions of American workers who don't have any health insurance at all, yet for now, at least, the government has chosen to expand the Medicare program for older Americans.

headline.main: The Nation: Future Shock; A $400 Billion Purchase, All on Credit

docs.abstract: Younger workers, many of whom lack health insurance, do not seem to be complaining about new Medicare prescription-drug benefit for elderly that will cost $400 billion over 10 years; apparently want their parents and grandparents to save money on drugs and have yet to focus on who will pay for program or how; all of benefits will be financed for now by borrowing; photo (M)2
docs.snippet: IN a perfectly equitable world, would the government have passed legislation that would give older Americans a prescription drug care plan that will cost $400 billion over 10 years?     To some economists, the prescription-drug benefit approved by...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 1,200 workers at the streamlined, automated plant here that makes Polartec, the popular cold-weather fabric, are having to live with the possibility that their jobs will be exported to China. If that happens, their chances of finding other work that pays as well are slim. The employees of Malden Mills Industries have been on such a precipice before, and now, as then, they are looking to their longtime leader, Aaron M. Feuerstein, as their best hope to keep working at one of the nation's most technologically advanced textile factories.

headline.main: Business; To Save Factories, Owners Diversify

docs.abstract: Proposal by Malden Mills Industries longtime leader Aaron M Feuerstein to raise money to buy company back from its creditors and keep needed textile jobs in Lawrence, Mass, by developing some old mill buildings into housing discussed as part of effort by factories across nation to fortify themselves with new revenue streams; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The hair is a bit shorter and tamer these days, the better to keep him from constantly sweeping the boyish tuft out of his eyes and with a side effect of making him look older than he did when he entered the race for the Democratic presidential nomination a year ago. On a more substantive level, the candidate, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, with the fervor of an encyclopedia salesman, brandishes a 60-page booklet full of policy positions at almost every stop, making clear that he has a stand on an array of important policy matters.

headline.main: A Surface vs. Substance Fight for Edwards

docs.abstract: Sen John Edwards, one-term senator, is dogged by questions about whether his relative inexperience in government, coupled with his boyish looks, is slowing his presidential campaign; many people say they favor his ideas but just cannot imagine him as president of the United States; he is trying to counter this impression by reminding voters at every opportunity that he is 50 years old; recent campaign commercial has him appearing in black and white, which has effect of making him seem bit older; his advisers say questions about his looks and bearing will vanish once voters see him up close; now in Iowa, he is on aggressive schedule of multiple stops; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The hair is a bit shorter and tamer these days, the better to keep him from constantly sweeping the boyish tuft out of his eyes and with a side effect of making him look older than he did when he entered the race for the Democratic presidential...

docs.lead_paragraph: A large industrial laundry in Queens, Jung Sun, agreed to a tentative contract yesterday, just nine hours after more than 100 of its workers went on strike. Union leaders said the workers walked out after Jung Sun insisted on a wage freeze and refused to accept a contract that was signed in recent days by 36 other New York City laundries.

headline.main: Laundry in Queens Agrees to Raise Pay After 9-Hour Strike

docs.abstract: Jung Sun industrial laundry in Queens (NYC) tentatively agrees to new contract after 100 workers strike in protest of wage freeze (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: This 30-second advertisement, the latest from Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, began running in Iowa on Wednesday. Its personal tone is similar to that of an advertisement for Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, which also addresses health care. PRODUCER: Morris & Carrick

headline.main: Gephardt Pushes His Health Care Plan With a Personal Story
